newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish president leads search for new government.
newsitem.headline: Turkish president leads search for new government.

text.p: Turkish President Suleyman Demirel starts consultations on Thursday to find a replacement for Necmettin Erbakan, forced to quit as prime minister by a military-led campaign against Islamists.
Demirel will meet five opposition figures before nominating a leader to try to forge a coalition government from the splintered parliament.
"You will be seeing me tomorrow (Thursday)," Anatolian news agency quoted a chirpy Demirel as telling reporters in reply to questions on how he would handle the government crisis.
Erbakan, the first Islamist to lead NATO member Turkey, resigned on Wednesday as the first step in a bid to hand power to coalition ally Tansu Ciller, a conservative.
Under the Erbakan plan, Ciller would head a caretaker coalition with the Islamists until early elections later this year. But Ciller, a U.S.-trained economist, is not guaranteed to get the job.
Demirel, a veteran politician whose current post is mostly symbolic, has given no clues as to who he would appoint as prime minister- designate.
Turkish political tradition says the president should give the job to main opposition leader Mesut Yilmaz, whose parliamentary strength is second only to that of Erbakan's Islam-based Welfare Party.
But Yilmaz may struggle to find coalition allies from among the fractious secularist parties.

His conservative rival Ciller would have a better chance of winning a parliamentary confidence vote as the head of a revamped coalition with the Islamists which would be supported by a small, far-right grouping.
Demirel has the power to appoint his own caretaker administration and call elections himself if his appointee fails to come up with a feasible government formula in 45 days.
Erbakan's coalition, set up only a year ago, crumbled in a secularist onslaught led by generals.
"Our country will now be freed of a false agenda and useless, needless tensions," he said in announcing his resignation.

The military, which has toppled three governments in the last four decades, has publicly pledged its readiness to turn back any threat to Turkey's secular order "by force of arms" -- tough talk that has alarmed close NATO ally the United States.

The mainstream media and business elite have also fed the current anti-Islamist hysteria, sparking enough defections among deputies and ministers from Ciller's conservatives to cost the coalition a majority in the 550-seat parliament.

A new government under Ciller would have the support on paper of 282 deputies, enough to pass a confidence vote. But anti-Islamist members of her True Path Party have threatened to abandon her if she does not make a complete break with Erbakan's Welfare Party.
